markdownRemark.html:
About

  • reactivex models data or events like a stream
  • we can provide callbacks for events like success, error or completion of this stream
  • real power is in the operators, which can help transform these streams easily in a declarative style
  • rxjs is the javascript implementation of reactivex standards

Observables

  • subscriber.next helps in sending data to the observers
  • observables are cold (lazy) by default i.e. unless there is an observer, data is not emitted
  • observable.subscribe receives an observer. behind the scenes, observers are converted to subscribers
  • all subsequent data is ignored after complete / error
  • observables are unicast i.e. each .subscribe() call has its own execution path i.e. different observers have different streams unaffected by one another
import { Observable } from "rxjs"

const observable = new Observable((subscriber) => {
  subscriber.next("hello")
  subscriber.next("world")
  subscriber.complete()
  subscriber.next("ignored")
})

const observer = {
  next: (value) => console.log("next:", value),
  error: (err) => console.log("error:", err),
  complete: () => console.log("complete"),
}

observable.subscribe(observer)

/*
OUTPUT

next: hello
next: world
complete
*/

Asynchronous Operations

  • observables can emit values asynchronously
  • we can return a function to perform cleanup logic
  • we can perform cleanup logic inside the complete part of observer as well
const observable = new Observable((subscriber) => {
  let count = 1
  const id = setInterval(() => {
    subscriber.next(count)
    count += 1
    if (count === 6) subscriber.complete()
  }, 1000)

  return () => {
    console.log("performing cleanup...")
    clearInterval(id)
  }
})

console.log("before")
observable.subscribe(observer)
console.log("after")

/*
OUTPUT

before
after
next: 1
next: 2
next: 3
next: 4
next: 5
complete
performing cleanup...
*/

Unsubscribing

  • .subscribe() returns a subscription, which can be used to unsubscribe the observer from the observable
  • when we unsubscribe manually, the complete callback isn’t called
// same as the earlier snippet

const subscription = observable.subscribe(observer)
setTimeout(() => subscription.unsubscribe(), 3500)

/*
OUTPUT

before
after
next: 1
next: 2
next: 3
performing cleanup...
*/

add

.add() on subscription helps in unsubscribing from multiple observers at once

const subscriptionOne = fromEvent(document, "click").subscribe(observer)
const subscriptionTwo = fromEvent(document, "click").subscribe(observer)

subscriptionOne.add(subscriptionTwo)

setTimeout(() => subscriptionOne.unsubscribe(), 3000)

Creation Operators

used for creating observables using built in robust creation operators

fromEvent(document, "click").subscribe(observer)

of(1, 2, 3, 4).subscribe(observer)

range(1, 5).subscribe(observer)

from([1, 2, 3]).subscribe(observer)
from(fetch("https://reqres.in/api/users").then((res) => res.json())).subscribe(
  observer
)

timer(1000).subscribe(observer)
timer(2000, 1000).subscribe(observer)

Pipeable Operators

  • pipeable operators don’t change existing observable i.e. they create a new observable without impacting the existing observable. example illustrating this using map operator - 
    const numbers$ = range(1, 5)
const numbersPlusTen$ = numbers$.pipe(operator)
numbers$.subscribe(observer) // still behaves the same way
  • there are two ways of applying operators -
    • operator1(config1)(operator2(config2)(observable$))
    • observable$.pipe(operator1(config1), operator2(config2))
  • the second method is preferred as it is more readable
  • we can also pass a function to pipe. in this case, the function receives the source observable, on which we can then call pipe. use case - changing behavior while testing 
    const piper = (x) => (source$) => source$.pipe(map((val) => val * x))
interval(1000).pipe(piper(10))

map

map to a new value using existing value

const numbers$ = range(1, 5)
const numbersPlusTen$ = numbers$.pipe(map((x) => x + 10))

pluck

pick out a (nested) property from an object

const keyUp$ = fromEvent(document, "keyup")
const keyCode$ = keyUp$.pipe(pluck("target", "nodeName"))
keyCode$.subscribe(observer)

filter

filter out data based on the boolean value returned from the predicate

range(1, 5)
  .pipe(filter((a) => a > 2))
  .subscribe(observer)

reduce

  • emit the accumulated value after the source observable completes
  • “pipe” method on observables uses reduce internally to compose operators
range(1, 5)
  .pipe(reduce((acc, x) => (console.log({ acc, x }), acc + x), 0))
  .subscribe(observer)

scan

like reduce, but emits the partial accumulated values as well

range(1, 5)
  .pipe(scan((acc, x) => acc + x, 0))
  .subscribe(observer)

tap

  • inspect observable values without impacting the observable behavior
  • we can pass an observer to tap
  • use tap for only debugging, and not for side effects
const counter$ = interval(1000).pipe(
  mapTo(-1),
  scan((acc, x) => acc + x, 10),
  tap(console.log),
  filter((x) => x >= 0)
)

counter$.subscribe(observer)

notice why our counter above is inefficient. we filter out all x which are negative, but that doesn’t stop the observables from continuing to run

take

return predetermined number of values, then stop the emission

range(1, 5).pipe(take(3)).subscribe(observer)

takeWhile

return values while the predicate returns true, then stop the emission

range(1, 5)
  .pipe(takeWhile((x) => x < 4))
  .subscribe(observer)

optimizing the counter discussed earlier -

const counter$ = interval(1000).pipe(
  mapTo(-1),
  scan((acc, x) => acc + x, 10),
  tap(console.log),
  takeWhile((x) => x >= 0)
)

counter$.subscribe(observer)

distinctUntilChanged

continuous duplicates are removed. though it uses === by default, we can supply a custom comparator

const loggedInStates = [{ name: "peter" }, { name: "peter" }, { name: "joey" }]

from(loggedInStates)
  .pipe(
    distinctUntilChanged((prev, curr) => prev.name === curr.name),
    pluck("name")
  )
  .subscribe(observer)

/*
OUTPUT

next: peter
next: joey
complete
*/

debounceTime and throttleTime

  • debounceTime - if time t has passed since the last emitted value from the observable, emit the value 
    const input_ = document.getElementById("input")

fromEvent(input_, "keyup")
  .pipe(debounceTime(1000), pluck("target", "value"), distinctUntilChanged())
  .subscribe(observer)
  • throttleTime - emit the value, ignore all values till time t, emit a value if the observable emits a value again
  • the syntax for both variants are the same
  • we can use asyncScheduler to customize behavior, e.g. specifying whether to use the leading or trailing value

takeUntil

emit values for the observable till the piped observable emits a value. example emit values till document is clicked

const timer$ = interval(1000)
const click$ = fromEvent(document, "click")
timer$.pipe(takeUntil(click$)).subscribe(observer)

mergeMap

subscribe to all the observables returned from the function passed to mergeMap and pass values emitted by them to the original subscriber. e.g. each document click results in mergeMap subscribing to a new interval observable

const click$ = fromEvent(document, "click")
const interval$ = interval(1000)

click$.pipe(mergeMap(() => interval$)).subscribe(console.log)

  • disadvantages of mergeMap -
    • subscribes to all observables, can result in a lot of observables, leading to memory leaks
    • responses can be out of order - imagine it is an http request. if the second request completes before the first request, since we will receive responses for both, they would be out of order
  • so, remember to clean up the inner observables. e.g. only run the interval till mouse pressed, then stop and start a new interval after the next mouse press
  • note: had we used takeUntil on the “outer pipe”, it would have stopped the entire observable, but we wanted to start a timer every mouse click. this is an important pattern found frequently
const mouseup$ = fromEvent(document, "mouseup")
const mousedown$ = fromEvent(document, "mousedown")
const interval$ = interval(1000)

mousedown$
  .pipe(mergeMap(() => interval$.pipe(takeUntil(mouseup$))))
  .subscribe(console.log)

switchMap

  • unsubscribe from the older observable, subscribe to the new observable
  • used when making get requests
const click$ = fromEvent(document, "click")
const interval$ = interval(1000)

click$.pipe(switchMap(() => interval$)).subscribe(console.log)

adding http requests to the typeahead functionality using switchMap -

fromEvent(input_, "keyup")
  .pipe(
    debounceTime(1000),
    pluck("target", "value"),
    distinctUntilChanged(),
    switchMap((name) => ajax.getJSON(`https://api.github.com/users/${name}`))
  )
  .subscribe(observer)

concatMap

  • queue up the inner observables
  • the inner observables wait till the active observable completes
  • use when observable has a finite lifespan
  • used when we want all requests to reach the server, that too in order

exhaustMap

  • throw away the new inner observable if the active inner observable hasn’t completed
  • use when making post requests

catchError

  • once an error occurs, an observable emits no more values
  • using catchError, we can return a new observable, which will replace the original observable and the observer continues normally
  • use case - we usually use catchError on the inner observable when making ajax requests, and return EMPTY so that the response is ignored. even if one of the inner observable fails, it doesn’t stop the entire observable from emitting values. e.g. adding error handling to the typeahead -
fromEvent(input_, "keyup")
  .pipe(
    debounceTime(1000),
    pluck("target", "value"),
    distinctUntilChanged(),
    switchMap((name) =>
      ajax
        .getJSON(`https://api.github.com/users/${name}`)
        .pipe(catchError((e) => EMPTY))
    )
  )
  .subscribe(observer)

finalize

  • we wanted to perform some logic after an inner observable got over. we supplied a function to finalize, which was used on the inner observable
  • what if we unsubscribe from the subscription? the onComplete passed inside observer won’t be called. however, the function inside finalize will be
  • perform logic when an error occurred, as an error stops the observable

startWith

  • emit an initial value on subscription before values from the actual observable
  • e.g. providing an initial value for interval observable, as it starts emitting after time t

toArray

accumulate emitted values to an array and emit the array. use case - testing

Combination Operators

create an observables from multiple observables

concat

second observable doesn’t start emitting till first is complete

const interval1$ = interval(100).pipe(take(3))
const interval2$ = interval(100).pipe(take(2))

concat(interval1$, interval2$).subscribe(observer)

/*
OUTPUT

next: 0
next: 1
next: 2
next: 0
next: 1
complete
*/

merge

emit value whenever any of the observables emits values

const keyup$ = fromEvent(document, "keyup")
const click$ = fromEvent(document, "click")

merge(keyup$, click$).subscribe(observer)

combineLatest

  • emit last value from each observable anytime an observable emits a value
  • doesn’t start emitting till all observables have emitted at least one value
const keyup$ = fromEvent(document, "keyup")
const click$ = fromEvent(document, "click")

combineLatest([keyup$, click$]).subscribe(observer)

forkJoin

  • emit last value from each observable after all the observables are complete
forkJoin([range(1, 5), range(1, 3)]).subscribe(observer)

Miscellaneous Examples

  • Countdown
  • Random Number Poller
  • Mortgage Calculator
